FRS_Method: GPS CARRIER PHASE STATIC RELATIVE POSITION

_desc.NAICS_DESCRIPTION: Broilers and Other Meat Type Chicken Production

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

PERDUE FARMS, INCORPORATED

GEORGETOWN, DELAWARE

2009

ANHYDROUS AMMONIA



Facility Description and Regulated Substances



Perdue Foods, LLC, founded in 1920, is the largest poultry producer in the Northeast and the third largest in the United States.  Headquartered in Salisbury, Maryland, the family-owned, privately held company has operations in nineteen states.  Fifteen processing facilities produce about 56 million pounds of poultry products each week.  Perdue also has grain storage and merchandising operations and is ranked among the top 12 largest US grain companies.  In addition, Perdue manufactures edible oils, specialty feeds, livestock feed ingredients and premium pet food.



The Perdue Georgetown Processing Facility (P-2178) is located at 20621 Savannah Road, Georgetown, Delaware. This facility is the primary source of production for roasters.  Perdue purchased this facility in 1978 and started operations in January 1979.  The facility is sited on about 70 acres on the north side of town, east of the town circle, about ? mile north of Route 9.  It is bounded by some residences and farmland.



Anhydrous ammonia is regulated under OSHA 29 CFR 1910.119 Process Safety Management and through 7 Delaware Code Chapter 77 (Accidental Release Prevention Regulation) where Delaware administers EPA 40 CFR Part 68 for Chemical Action Prevention Provisions.   



It is used onsite for chilling processes and refrigeration of product. The Georgetown facility has four separate ammonia systems ranging from 7,400 pounds to 30,000 pounds.  In each system, ammonia is distributed throughout the components (compressors, condensers, evaporators, etc.).  Each system has equipment both inside and outside the facility.   The total ammonia storage in all four systems onsite is 72,600 pounds.



Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies



As a concerned member of the communities in which Perdue facilities are located, the company takes its

role as a responsible corporate citizen very seriously. All Perdue facilities are operated to protect employees, contractors and the public from injury and illness, and to minimize environmental impact.  A company-wide safety and wellness program stresses safe conditions and safe practices.  Perdue's policy is to inspect, maintain and operate equipment and facilities to prevent accidents, including any release of a hazardous material.  Key employees are trained in prevention and responses for rapid and effective action should an accident occur.



Perdue has developed and implemented Spill Prevention Control and Countermeasures (SPCC) and Process Safety Management (PSM) plans at each facility as part of an overall chemical management program.  The program involves a wide range of personnel.  Additionally, Perdue conducts regular safety meetings and provides a wide variety of environmental, health and safety training to its staff.



Accident Release Prevention Program



Perdue Georgetown has complied with Delaware's Accidental Release Prevention Regulation (formerly Extremely Hazardous Substance Risk Management Act) since its promulgation in 1989 and the OSHA Process Safety Management Regulation 29 CFR 1910.119 since its inception in 1992.  Up-to-date process information such as equipment information, piping and instrument diagrams and Material Safety Data Sheets, are kept onsite.  Employee participation includes operating and maintenance procedures development, review and training.  Contractors are required to submit qualification statements of competency.  Process Hazard Analyses with recommendations have been done, and corrective actions taken. Regular mechanical integrity inspections are scheduled.  In addition, Perdue performs internal audits on its PSM processes. 



Five-Year Accident History



There have been no on- or off-site accidents involving anhydrous ammonia at the Perdue Georgetown facility that have resulted in death, injuries, property damage or

environmental damage.



Emergency Response Program



Perdue Georgetown has implemented a comprehensive Emergency Response Plan in accordance with the OSHA PSM regulations.  The facility has a trained HAZWOPER (HAZardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response) team that will respond in the event of a hazardous material release or other emergency situation.  The Plan contains specific information regarding emergency response organization and procedures, as well as incident notification, mitigation and incident preparedness.  Evacuation exercises are conducted, and drills are scheduled with emergency responders.  Perdue Georgetown is a member of the Sussex County Local Emergency Planning Committee and is part of the community emergency response plan.  Perdue staff regularly attends Sussex LEPC meetings.   



Planned Changes to Improve Safety



Perdue continues to make improvements to the ammonia refrigeration systems and to identify and update system components and techniques to ensure safety and quality.   Currently, planned improvements include change out of all pressure-relief valves over a five-year cycle.   Other potential improvements will be based on annual inspections, audits, process hazard analyses and/or mechanical integrity inspections.
